Aerodynamics Modules¶

Contents¶

Atmosphere

pyavia.aero.Atmosphere

An Atmosphere class giving a fixed representation of atmospheric conditions.

pyavia.aero.geo_alt_to_pot

Convert geometric altitude to geopotential h → H per ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 8.

pyavia.aero.pot_alt_to_geo

Convert geopotential altitude to geometric H → h per ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 9.

General Gases

pyavia.aero.Gas

Abstract Base class representing common properties of gases, including 1-D flow properties.

Perfect Gases

pyavia.aero.PerfectGas

A simplified thermally and calorically perfect gas, i.e. c_p and R are constant.

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.enthalpy

Returns the specific enthalpy of a perfect gas, computed using \({h} = h_{ref} + c_p (T - T_{ref})\)

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.stag_press_ratio

Returns the ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static pressure of a perfect gas, computed using \(\frac{P_0}{P} = (1 + \frac{1}{2}(γ - 1)M^2)^{\frac{γ}{γ - 1}}\).

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.stag_temp_ratio

Returns the ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static temperature of a perfect gas, computed using \(\frac{T_0}{T} = 1 + \frac{1}{2}(γ - 1)M^2\).

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.temp_from_enthalpy

Returns the static temperature of a perfect gas, based on the specific enthalpy, computed using \({T} = T_{ref} + (h - h_{ref}) / c_p\)

Imperfect Gases

pyavia.aero.ImperfectGas

Imperfect gas using polynomials from Walsh & Fletcher §3.

Members¶

Functions relating to aerodynamics, thermodynamics and fluid dynamics.

class pyavia.aero.Atmosphere(**kwargs)¶

Bases: object

An Atmosphere class giving a fixed representation of atmospheric conditions. Once constructed, all of the regular assosicated atmospheric properties are then made available through class properties.

Examples

Set default result units as US or SI. Individual defaults can be set for each unit type:

>>> Atmosphere.set_default_style('SI')
>>> Atmosphere.unitdef_press = 'psi'

Show some ISA SSL values:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H='SSL')
>>> print(f"P = {atm.pressure:.3f}, T = {atm.temperature:.2f}")
P = 14.696 psi, T = 288.15 K

Show density for an ISA standard altitude (note that these are formally geopotential altitudes):

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H=dim(10000, 'ft'))
>>> print(f"ρ = {atm.ρ:.3f}")
ρ = 0.905 kg/m³

Show the temperature ratio for a pressure altitude with a temperature offset:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H_press=dim(34000,'ft'), T_offset=dim(+15,'Δ°C'))
>>> print(f"Theta = {atm.theta:.3f}")
Theta = 0.818

Show the density ratio for an arbitrary non-standard atmosphere based on temperature / pressure:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(P=dim(90, 'kPa'), T=dim(-15, '°C'))
>>> print(f"σ = {atm.σ:.3f}")
σ = 0.991
property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶
R = Dim(287.05287, 'J/K/kg')¶
property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶
__annotations__ = {'P': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'T': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'a': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'γ': <class 'float'>, 'δ': <class 'float'>, 'θ': <class 'float'>, 'μ': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'ν': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'ρ': <class 'pyavia.units.Dim'>, 'σ': <class 'float'>}¶
__init__(**kwargs)¶

Construct an atmosphere using a variety of possible methods, depending on the arguments provided.

Parameters

kwargs –

The following keyword combinations can be used. In each case the associated value must be a Dim object, e.g. H = dim(5000, 'ft'):

  • H:

    • If H == ‘SSL’: Construct an ISA standard sea level atmosphere..

    • If ‘H’ is a Dim object: Construct an ISA standard atmosphere corresponding to a given geopotential altitude. This is generally what is used in most texts (assumes gravity fixed across altitudes). Note the uppercase H.

  • h_geometric: ISA standard atmosphere corresponding to a given geometric altitude.

  • T, P: Arbitrary atmosphere with given temperature and pressure.

  • H_press, T: Arbitrary atmosphere based on pressure altitude (altimeter set to 1013 mb / 29.92 in-Hg) and a given temperature.

  • H_press, T_offset: Same as H_press, T except temperature is given as an offset from the ISA standard value at that pressure altitude.

property a: pyavia.units.Dim¶

\(a = \sqrt{\gamma RT}\).

property delta: float¶

\(\delta = P / P_{SSL}\).

property density: pyavia.units.Dim¶
property density_altitude: pyavia.units.Dim¶

After finding the correct altitude range, density altitude is computed using a root bisection method, as it is non-linear.

property dynamic_viscosity: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Dynamic viscosity (μ) also just called ‘viscosity’. It is computed using the empirical Sutherland equation shown in ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 22. It is invalid for very high or low temperatures and conditions at altitudes above 90 km.

property gamma: float¶

\(\gamma = c_p/c_v\) ratio of specific heats. This is presently set to a constant \(γ = 1.4\) which is valid for all ambient atmospheres which are relatively cold.

property kinematic_viscosity: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Kinematic viscosity \(\nu = \mu/\rho\).

property pressure: pyavia.units.Dim¶
property pressure_altitude: pyavia.units.Dim¶
classmethod set_default_style(style: str = 'US')¶

Setting to give default results in style=’US’ or ‘SI’ units.

property sigma: float¶

\(\sigma = \rho/\rho_{SSL}\).

property speed_of_sound: pyavia.units.Dim¶

\(a = \sqrt{\gamma RT}\).

property temperature: pyavia.units.Dim¶
property theta: float¶

\(\theta = T/T_{SSL}\).

unitdef_alt = 'ft'¶
unitdef_dens = 'slug/ft^3'¶
unitdef_kine = 'ft²/s'¶
unitdef_press = 'psf'¶
unitdef_spd = 'ft/s'¶
unitdef_temp = '°R'¶
unitdef_visc = 'psf.s'¶
property γ: float¶

\(\gamma = c_p/c_v\) ratio of specific heats. This is presently set to a constant \(γ = 1.4\) which is valid for all ambient atmospheres which are relatively cold.

property δ: float¶

\(\delta = P / P_{SSL}\).

property θ: float¶

\(\theta = T/T_{SSL}\).

property μ: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Dynamic viscosity (μ) also just called ‘viscosity’. It is computed using the empirical Sutherland equation shown in ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 22. It is invalid for very high or low temperatures and conditions at altitudes above 90 km.

property ν: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Kinematic viscosity \(\nu = \mu/\rho\).

property ρ: pyavia.units.Dim¶
property σ: float¶

\(\sigma = \rho/\rho_{SSL}\).

class pyavia.aero.Gas(*, R: pyavia.units.Dim, w: pyavia.units.Dim = Dim(0.0, 'kg/s'), FAR: float = 0.0)¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract Base class representing common properties of gases, including 1-D flow properties. Gas objects are not intended to be modified after initialisation - they simply allow access to all the gas properties, which are fixed.

property FAR: float¶

Fuel-Air Ratio \(FAR = w_f / w_{total}\) where \(w_f\) is the massflow of fuel products of combustion and \(w_{total}\) is the total massflow. E.G. If the upstream flow was pure airflow of \(w_{air}\) then \(FAR = w_f / (w_f + w_{air})\). The base class implementation simply returns the initialisation value.

abstract property M: float¶

Mach number \(M = u/a\).

abstract property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static pressure.

abstract property P0¶

Total / stagnation pressure.

property Q¶

Enthalpy flowrate Q = h * w. Units determined by multiplication.

property R: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Gas constant R for the specific gas. R_specific = R_universal / M where R = 8.314462618 kg.m².s⁻².K⁻¹.mol⁻¹ and M is molar mass [kg/mol].

abstract property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static temperature.

abstract property T0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation temperature.

__init__(*, R: pyavia.units.Dim, w: pyavia.units.Dim = Dim(0.0, 'kg/s'), FAR: float = 0.0)¶
Parameters

  • R (Dim) – Gas constant for the gas (i.e. \(R = R_{univ}/n\)).

  • w (Dim) – Mass flowrate.

  • FAR (float) – Fuel-Air Ratio \(FAR = w_f/w_{total}\). Non-zero FAR occurs when gases include products of combustion.

property a: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Local speed of sound \(a = \sqrt{{\gamma}RT}\).

abstract property c_p: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific heat capacity at constant pressure of the gas.

property c_v: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific heat capacity at constant volume of the gas.

abstract property gamma: float¶

Ratio of specific heats \(\gamma = c_p/c_v.\)

abstract property h: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific enthalpy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property h0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation enthalpy of the gas, assuming it is brought to rest with losses or heat transfer computed as \(h_0 = h + \frac{1}{2}u^2\). Like all enthalpy values the baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property rho: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Density ρ = P/(R.T).

abstract property s: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific entropy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

abstract property u: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Flow velocity.

property w: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Mass flowrate.

class pyavia.aero.ImperfectGas(*, gas: str = 'air', FAR: float = 0.0, init_gas: Optional[pyavia.aero.gas.Gas] = None, **kwargs)¶

Bases: pyavia.aero.gas.Gas

Imperfect gas using polynomials from Walsh & Fletcher §3. Includes optional products of combustion. Properties are fixed once initialised.

Note

  • Temperature range is 200 K → 2000 K.

  • Fuel-Air Ratio FAR = 0.00 → 0.05

  • Non-linear \(\gamma\), \(c_p\), h, s dependent on temperature (i.e. calorically imperfect). Stagnation enthalpy, temperature and pressure also do not assume a perfect gas. Stagnation properties are computed by bringing the flow to rest isentropically.

  • Internal values stored as SI units [K, kPa, …].

  • Stream / static temperature and pressure and Mach number are the internal reference states.

property M: float¶

Mach number \(M = u/a\).

property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static pressure.

property P0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation pressure.

property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static temperature.

property T0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation temperature.

__init__(*, gas: str = 'air', FAR: float = 0.0, init_gas: Optional[pyavia.aero.gas.Gas] = None, **kwargs)¶

Construct a compressible, imperfect gas, based on interpolating polynomials given in Walsh & Fletcher, “Gas Turbine Performance”, Second Edition, Chapter 3.

Parameters

  • gas (str) –

    Gas identifier. Available gas values are:

    • ’air’: Dry air (default).

    • ’burned_kerosene’: Products of combustion for kerosene in dry air.

    • ’burned_diesel’: Products of combustion for diesel in dry air.

  • FAR (float) – Refer to GasFlow for details.

  • init_gas (Gas) – If T, P, M are not directly specified for the gas, init_gas can be provided which will be a gas with very similar properties to those requested. For example, this can be a previous solution point. This can act as a starting point so as to accelerate convergence / solution of the gas equations. If not required it is ignored.

  • kwargs ({str: Dim | float}) – Required state properties of the gas flow, supplied as a dict. Refer to PerfectGasFlow initialisation for requirements.

  • init_gasflow (GasFlow (Optional)) – If provided, relevant properties from this reference gasflow are used as a starting point to accelerate the construction / convergence of the new gasflow.

property c_p: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific heat capacity at constant pressure of the gas.

property gamma: float¶

Ratio of specific heats \(\gamma = c_p/c_v.\)

property gas: str¶

Identifier for the gas. Refer to __init__ for details.

property h: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific enthalpy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property s: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific entropy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property u: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Flow velocity.

class pyavia.aero.PerfectGas(*, gas: str = 'air', gamma: float = 1.4, **kwargs)¶

Bases: pyavia.aero.gas.Gas

A simplified thermally and calorically perfect gas, i.e. c_p and R are constant. Once initialised, properties are fixed.

Note

  • Internal working parameters are stream pressure, temperature, Mach number and ratio of specific heats (P, T, M, γ).

  • Sepcific enthalpy computation is \(h = h_ref + c_p.(T - T_{ref})\).

  • Specific entropy computation is \(s = s_ref + c_p.ln(T / T_{ref}) - R.ln(P / P_{ref})\).

Reference values for air:

  • P_ref = 100 kPa. Note this is 1 bar, not an ISA standard atmosphere.

  • T_ref = 298.15 K.

  • h_ref = 720.76 kJ/kg.

  • s_ref = 5.68226 kJ/kg/K.

property M: float¶

Mach number \(M = u/a\).

property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static pressure.

property P0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation pressure.

property P0_P: float¶

Ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static pressure.

property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static temperature.

property T0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation temperature.

property T0_T: float¶

Ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static temperature.

__init__(*, gas: str = 'air', gamma: float = 1.4, **kwargs)¶

Construct a thermally and calorically perfect gas with 1-D flow properties.

Parameters

  • gas (str) –

    Gas idenfitifer, used to set R and reference values. Supported values for this model are:

    • ’air’ (default).

  • gamma (float) –

    Ratio of specific heats. Commonly used values for air are:

    • γ = 1.4: Atmospheric air, compressors (default).

    • γ = 1.33: Hot air, burners, turbines.

  • kwargs ({str: Dim | float}) –

    Remaining arguments must include three state properties that properly define the gas. These can be supplied in any combination provided they fully define the state, e.g. {‘P’: dim(101.325, ‘kPa’), ‘T’: dim(288.15, ‘K’), ‘M’: 0.0}.

    Available properties are:

    • P0: Total / stagnation pressure.

    • T0: Total / stagnation temperature.

    • P: Stream / static pressure.

    • T: Stream / static temperature.

    • h: Specific enthalpy.

    • h0: Total / stagnation enthalpy.

    • s: Specific entropy.

    • M: Mach number.

    If P, T and M are supplied these are directly set and initialisation is complete. Other combinations are converted into these values using perfect gas equations or iterative convergence of T, P and M.

property c_p: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific heat capacity at constant pressure of the gas.

property gamma: float¶

Ratio of specific heats \(\gamma = c_p/c_v.\)

property h: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific enthalpy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property s: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific entropy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property u: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Flow velocity.

pyavia.aero.geo_alt_to_pot(geo_alt: pyavia.units.Dim) → pyavia.units.Dim¶

Convert geometric altitude to geopotential h → H per ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 8.

pyavia.aero.pot_alt_to_geo(pot_alt: pyavia.units.Dim) → pyavia.units.Dim¶

Convert geopotential altitude to geometric H → h per ISO 2533-1975 Eqn 9.

Atmospheric property calculations including the ISA.

Contains:

Atmosphere Class giving fixed atmospheric properties. geo_alt_to_pot Function converting geometric altitude to geopotential. pot_alt_to_geo Function converting geopotential altitude to geometric.

Notes:

  • Uses ISO 2533-1975 International Standard Atmsosphere (ISA). Altitude

    from -2 → +80 km

  • The ISA is defined in terms of geopotential altitude (H) which is

    convenient when computing the pressure distribution through the depth of the atmosphere. This assumes a constant value of gravitational acceleration everywhere. In reality, gravitational acceleration falls slightly as geometric (actual) altitude (h) increases. H and h are related by an equation; use geo_alt_to_pot() and pot_alt_to_geo() for conversion. Unless noted otherwise, all altitudes used in Atmosphere are geopotential (H).

  • Humidity is not presently included.

  • Dynamic viscosity is computed via Sutherland’s formula which is reasonably

    accurate between 180°R - 3400°R (or 100K - 1889K, -173 - 1616°C, ref NACA TN 1135).

  • Uppercase and lowercase are mixed to be consistent with source documents.

    Uppercase H and associated values refer to geopotential altitudes, lowercase refer to geometric (but these don’t appear together anyway so as to prevent errors).

  • Some non-ASCII characters are used.

class pyavia.aero.atmosphere.Atmosphere(**kwargs)¶

Bases: object

An Atmosphere class giving a fixed representation of atmospheric conditions. Once constructed, all of the regular assosicated atmospheric properties are then made available through class properties.

Examples

Set default result units as US or SI. Individual defaults can be set for each unit type:

>>> Atmosphere.set_default_style('SI')
>>> Atmosphere.unitdef_press = 'psi'

Show some ISA SSL values:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H='SSL')
>>> print(f"P = {atm.pressure:.3f}, T = {atm.temperature:.2f}")
P = 14.696 psi, T = 288.15 K

Show density for an ISA standard altitude (note that these are formally geopotential altitudes):

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H=dim(10000, 'ft'))
>>> print(f"ρ = {atm.ρ:.3f}")
ρ = 0.905 kg/m³

Show the temperature ratio for a pressure altitude with a temperature offset:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(H_press=dim(34000,'ft'), T_offset=dim(+15,'Δ°C'))
>>> print(f"Theta = {atm.theta:.3f}")
Theta = 0.818

Show the density ratio for an arbitrary non-standard atmosphere based on temperature / pressure:

>>> atm = Atmosphere(P=dim(90, 'kPa'), T=dim(-15, '°C'))
>>> print(f"σ = {atm.σ:.3f}")
σ = 0.991

Construct an atmosphere using a variety of possible methods, depending on the arguments provided.

Parameters

kwargs –

The following keyword combinations can be used. In each case the associated value must be a Dim object, e.g. H = dim(5000, 'ft'):

  • H:

    • If H == ‘SSL’: Construct an ISA standard sea level atmosphere..

    • If ‘H’ is a Dim object: Construct an ISA standard atmosphere corresponding to a given geopotential altitude. This is generally what is used in most texts (assumes gravity fixed across altitudes). Note the uppercase H.

  • h_geometric: ISA standard atmosphere corresponding to a given geometric altitude.

  • T, P: Arbitrary atmosphere with given temperature and pressure.

  • H_press, T: Arbitrary atmosphere based on pressure altitude (altimeter set to 1013 mb / 29.92 in-Hg) and a given temperature.

  • H_press, T_offset: Same as H_press, T except temperature is given as an offset from the ISA standard value at that pressure altitude.

class pyavia.aero.gas.Gas(*, R: pyavia.units.Dim, w: pyavia.units.Dim = Dim(0.0, 'kg/s'), FAR: float = 0.0)¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract Base class representing common properties of gases, including 1-D flow properties. Gas objects are not intended to be modified after initialisation - they simply allow access to all the gas properties, which are fixed.

property FAR: float¶

Fuel-Air Ratio \(FAR = w_f / w_{total}\) where \(w_f\) is the massflow of fuel products of combustion and \(w_{total}\) is the total massflow. E.G. If the upstream flow was pure airflow of \(w_{air}\) then \(FAR = w_f / (w_f + w_{air})\). The base class implementation simply returns the initialisation value.

abstract property M: float¶

Mach number \(M = u/a\).

abstract property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static pressure.

abstract property P0¶

Total / stagnation pressure.

property Q¶

Enthalpy flowrate Q = h * w. Units determined by multiplication.

property R: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Gas constant R for the specific gas. R_specific = R_universal / M where R = 8.314462618 kg.m².s⁻².K⁻¹.mol⁻¹ and M is molar mass [kg/mol].

abstract property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static temperature.

abstract property T0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation temperature.

__init__(*, R: pyavia.units.Dim, w: pyavia.units.Dim = Dim(0.0, 'kg/s'), FAR: float = 0.0)¶
Parameters

  • R (Dim) – Gas constant for the gas (i.e. \(R = R_{univ}/n\)).

  • w (Dim) – Mass flowrate.

  • FAR (float) – Fuel-Air Ratio \(FAR = w_f/w_{total}\). Non-zero FAR occurs when gases include products of combustion.

property a: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Local speed of sound \(a = \sqrt{{\gamma}RT}\).

Specific enthalpy of the gas.

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property h0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation enthalpy of the gas, assuming it is brought to rest with losses or heat transfer computed as \(h_0 = h + \frac{1}{2}u^2\). Like all enthalpy values the baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

class pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.PerfectGas(*, gas: str = 'air', gamma: float = 1.4, **kwargs)¶

Bases: pyavia.aero.gas.Gas

A simplified thermally and calorically perfect gas, i.e. c_p and R are constant. Once initialised, properties are fixed.

Note

  • Internal working parameters are stream pressure, temperature, Mach number and ratio of specific heats (P, T, M, γ).

  • Sepcific enthalpy computation is \(h = h_ref + c_p.(T - T_{ref})\).

  • Specific entropy computation is \(s = s_ref + c_p.ln(T / T_{ref}) - R.ln(P / P_{ref})\).

Reference values for air:

  • P_ref = 100 kPa. Note this is 1 bar, not an ISA standard atmosphere.

  • T_ref = 298.15 K.

  • h_ref = 720.76 kJ/kg.

  • s_ref = 5.68226 kJ/kg/K.

property M: float¶

Mach number \(M = u/a\).

property P: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static pressure.

property P0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation pressure.

property P0_P: float¶

Ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static pressure.

property T: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Stream / static temperature.

property T0: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Total / stagnation temperature.

property T0_T: float¶

Ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static temperature.

__init__(*, gas: str = 'air', gamma: float = 1.4, **kwargs)¶

Construct a thermally and calorically perfect gas with 1-D flow properties.

Parameters

  • gas (str) –

    Gas idenfitifer, used to set R and reference values. Supported values for this model are:

    • ’air’ (default).

  • gamma (float) –

    Ratio of specific heats. Commonly used values for air are:

    • γ = 1.4: Atmospheric air, compressors (default).

    • γ = 1.33: Hot air, burners, turbines.

  • kwargs ({str: Dim | float}) –

    Remaining arguments must include three state properties that properly define the gas. These can be supplied in any combination provided they fully define the state, e.g. {‘P’: dim(101.325, ‘kPa’), ‘T’: dim(288.15, ‘K’), ‘M’: 0.0}.

    Available properties are:

    • P0: Total / stagnation pressure.

    • T0: Total / stagnation temperature.

    • P: Stream / static pressure.

    • T: Stream / static temperature.

    • h: Specific enthalpy.

    • h0: Total / stagnation enthalpy.

    • s: Specific entropy.

    • M: Mach number.

    If P, T and M are supplied these are directly set and initialisation is complete. Other combinations are converted into these values using perfect gas equations or iterative convergence of T, P and M.

property c_p: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific heat capacity at constant pressure of the gas.

property gamma: float¶

Ratio of specific heats \(\gamma = c_p/c_v.\)

property h: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific enthalpy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property s: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Specific entropy of the gas.

Note

The baseline is arbitrary and values from different formulations / classes should not be compared.

property u: pyavia.units.Dim¶

Flow velocity.

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.enthalpy(T: pyavia.units.Dim, c_p: pyavia.units.Dim, T_ref: pyavia.units.Dim, h_ref: pyavia.units.Dim) → pyavia.units.Dim¶

Returns the specific enthalpy of a perfect gas, computed using \({h} = h_{ref} + c_p (T - T_{ref})\)

Note

Enthalpies can only be compared if they have common reference conditions.

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.stag_press_ratio(gamma: float, M: float) → float¶

Returns the ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static pressure of a perfect gas, computed using \(\frac{P_0}{P} = (1 + \frac{1}{2}(γ - 1)M^2)^{\frac{γ}{γ - 1}}\).

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.stag_temp_ratio(gamma: float, M: float) → float¶

Returns the ratio of total (stagnation) pressure to static temperature of a perfect gas, computed using \(\frac{T_0}{T} = 1 + \frac{1}{2}(γ - 1)M^2\).

pyavia.aero.perfect_gas.temp_from_enthalpy(h_: pyavia.units.Dim, c_p: pyavia.units.Dim, T_ref: pyavia.units.Dim, h_ref: pyavia.units.Dim) → pyavia.units.Dim¶

Returns the static temperature of a perfect gas, based on the specific enthalpy, computed using \({T} = T_{ref} + (h - h_{ref}) / c_p\)
